repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
continues https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/29064

<details>
<summary>old rejected proposal</summary>

## Problem

keymap.set accepts `opts` as the last parameter, but that is awkward because:

1. it doesn't match the order of `:nnoremap`
2. it's preferred that the "callback" arg of most stdlib functions is the *last* parameter, because it leads to more readable code (and other benefits, such as potential for promise-like functionality in the future).

## Solution

- add an overloaded signature so that `opts` can be arg 2. `function keymap.set(mode, opts, lhs, rhs)`
- The old signature is still supported.

### Comparison

Before:

    vim.keymap.set('n', 'crr', function()
      vim.lsp.buf.code_action()
    end, { desc = 'vim.lsp.buf.code_action()' })

After (opts is now arg 2 instead of arg 4):

    vim.keymap.set('n', { desc = 'vim.lsp.buf.code_action()' }, 'crr', function()
      vim.lsp.buf.code_action()
    end)

</details>


closes https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/28536

comment_data.body: This kind of case seems like a clear readability improvement.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -159,53 +164,73 @@ do
   ---
   --- See |grr|, |grn|, |gra|, |i_CTRL-S|.
   do
-    vim.keymap.set('n', 'grn', function()
+    vim.keymap.set('n', { desc = 'vim.lsp.buf.rename()' }, 'grn', function()
       vim.lsp.buf.rename()
-    end, { desc = 'vim.lsp.buf.rename()' })
+    end)
 
-    vim.keymap.set({ 'n', 'x' }, 'gra', function()
+    vim.keymap.set({ 'n', 'x' }, { desc = 'vim.lsp.buf.code_action()' }, 'gra', function()
       vim.lsp.buf.code_action()
-    end, { desc = 'vim.lsp.buf.code_action()' })
+    end)
 
-    vim.keymap.set('n', 'grr', function()
+    vim.keymap.set('n', { desc = 'vim.lsp.buf.references()' }, 'grr', function()
       vim.lsp.buf.references()
-    end, { desc = 'vim.lsp.buf.references()' })
+    end)

comment_data.body: This case is arguably a regression?

       return '\27' .. search_cmd
     end
 
-    vim.keymap.set('x', '*', function()
-      return _visual_search('/')
-    end, { desc = ':help v_star-default', expr = true, silent = true })
-    vim.keymap.set('x', '#', function()
+    vim.keymap.set(
+      'x',
+      { desc = ':help v_star-default', expr = true, silent = true },
+      '*',
+      function()
+        return _visual_search('/')
+      end
+    )

comment_data.body: I personally think it's a sideways change. To me both are just as readable.

comment_data.body:
Throwing in my unsolicited 2 cents, but I think it is a readability improvement for larger functions (and somewhat sideways change for 1 line like in this case), so as a whole I personally believe function last is overall more readable.

Before:

```lua
vim.keymap.set('n', 'grr', function()
    local lang = vim.treesitter.language.inspect('c')
    local keys, symbols = {}, {}
    for k, v in pairs(lang) do
        if type(v) == 'boolean' then
            keys[k] = v
        else
            keys[k] = true
        end
    end
    return { keys, lang.fields, symbols }
end, { desc = 'vim.lsp.buf.references()' })
```

After:

```lua
vim.keymap.set('n', 'grr', { desc = 'vim.lsp.buf.references()' }, function()
    local lang = vim.treesitter.language.inspect('c')
    local keys, symbols = {}, {}
    for k, v in pairs(lang) do
        if type(v) == 'boolean' then
            keys[k] = v
        else
            keys[k] = true
        end
    end
    return { keys, lang.fields, symbols }
end)
```

comment_data.body:
I think the litmus test is with bigger `opts` tables so stylua puts them on multiple lines. If the fit into a single line, it really makes no difference whether it is before the `function()` or after the `end`.

(Personally I -- much -- prefer the latter, since the `end)` line is wasted anyway, so might as well put something meaningful there. And having the `opts` before the `function` can push that too far to the right, making the arguments less visible.)

comment_data.body:
With multiple opts tables it becomes

```lua
vim.keymap.set('n', 'grr', function()
    local lang = vim.treesitter.language.inspect('c')
    local keys, symbols = {}, {}
    for k, v in pairs(lang) do
        if type(v) == 'boolean' then
            keys[k] = v
        else
            keys[k] = true
        end
    end
    return { keys, lang.fields, symbols }
end, {
    desc = 'vim.lsp.buf.references()',
    another_desc = 'vim.lsp.buf.references()!',
    final_desc = 'vim.lsp.buf.references()?',
})
```

vs

```lua
vim.keymap.set('n', 'grr', {
    desc = 'vim.lsp.buf.references()',
    another_desc = 'vim.lsp.buf.references()!',
    final_desc = 'vim.lsp.buf.references()?',
}, function()
    local lang = vim.treesitter.language.inspect('c')
    local keys, symbols = {}, {}
    for k, v in pairs(lang) do
        if type(v) == 'boolean' then
            keys[k] = v
        else
            keys[k] = true
        end
    end
    return { keys, lang.fields, symbols }
end)
```

Yeah, maybe the difference isn't that big after all. I don't have a good argument for the latter except that it *feels* better lol.

comment_data.body:
@dundargoc yeah, that's definitely true. What discouraged me is that if the options list gets big, it's kind of "back to square one". With a big `opts` list, the LHS is sitting the middle of a bunch of stuff:

```lua
vim.keymap.set(
  'n',
  { desc = 'vim.lsp.buf.references()', ... },
  'grr',
  function()
    local lang = vim.treesitter.language.inspect('c')
    local keys, symbols = {}, {}
    for k, v in pairs(lang) do
      if type(v) == 'boolean' then
        keys[k] = v
      else
        keys[k] = true
      end
    end
    return { keys, lang.fields, symbols }
  end)
```

And since there's little enthusiasm for it I'm just gonna punt. 

I'm happy to revive it again later if that changes; the logic changes were [small](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/commit/a96a0dbdddfcd9102d177c07355587a5890d6dec). 

Meanwhile, I started to doubt that the cost of "multiple ways to do something" was being offset.

       vim.lsp.buf.references()
-    end, { desc = 'vim.lsp.buf.references()' })
+    end)

comment_regular_data.body:
> it's common and recommended that opts is near the front of the parameter list, not the end

Huh? `opts` is common and recommended being at the end of a parameter list.

And just for reference, this change has a lot of objections: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/29064#issuecomment-2139106757

I think the overload is ok as long as the current signature remains the main one that is documented, or, document using the `[{opts} ,]` syntax (somehow?).

> > it's common and recommended that opts is near the front of the parameter list, not the end
> 
> Huh? `opts` is common and recommended being at the end of a parameter list.

True, I removed that item. `opts` is similar to a callback in that it can be "noisy" and so it's preferred near the end. But callbacks are more noisy, so they should follow `opts`.

> this change has a lot of objections: [#29064 (comment)](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/29064#issuecomment-2139106757)

That was not the same change. The proposal at the time of those objections placed `opts` in the middle (`lhs, opts, rhs`), which I agree is janky.
It's also worth considering that `lhs` is required and `opts` is optional. It's only used 50% in my mappings which means non-opts is very common.
Ok I'll probably drop this change and update this PR to only include docs updates and extra test coverage.

title: refactor(lua): vim.keymap.set tests, docs
